Posts.Title: Surgery in 2 days ChicagoGirl ChicagoGirl

Posts.Content: ChicagoGirl wrote: Sometimes I just feel like giving up on the whole dating thing. It's really hard dating and having to tell an individual what's going on in your life. I'm to the point where I just feel like passing out index cards with my medical history on them and getting the rejection part over with. In the beginning when meeting guys I found myself to be very blunt which I think scared them off but I looked at it as let's just get this out the way therefore no one's time is wasted. Now I've learned to discuss things when I feel comfortable, it's not about them but more so about me, I've learned to let an individual get to know me first verses the girl diagnosed with cancer.. I'm still finding this is not to be easy to tell new people and I guess it never will, I think I've taught myself to become numb to rejection and allowing myself to catch feelings for an individual but I don't want to be alone in this. I've been recently dating a guy for 3 months now and he's a really nice guy. I told him my situation about a week or so ago and now I feel like I'm waiting on the other shoe to drop, his reaction was normal and he shared with my his mom passed of breast cancer and his sister recently finished treatment. I'm just hoping nothing will change, for now we're just dating and taking things slow which is fine but I've been here before and it seems some people do not know how to be upfront with their true feelings.. thank you ladies for being here and sharing you stories and thoughts.. (()) Dx 10/21/2012, 6cm+, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Targeted Therapy 11/4/2012 Tykerb (lapatinib) Chemotherapy 1/31/2013 Taxotere (docetaxel) Targeted Therapy 11/4/2013 Herceptin (trastuzumab) Surgery 11/19/2013 Lymph node removal: Right; Mastectomy: Right Surgery Reconstruction (right): Latissimus dorsi flap Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Dating Thru Cancer ChicagoGirl DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2016 10:43AM ChicagoGirl wrote: Hello Shutterbug, I have been off chemo since November to prepare for the reconstructive surgery, now that the surgery has been done I begin chemo again next week. The TDM1 is working well and I have been stable for over 2yrs now. But I can't help but to wonder if I have been doing well without chemo since November and everything is well can something be altered. My regimen is every three weeks for the TDM1 and every 6wks for the Xgeva shot. However as we all know it has been said with Stage 4 you will possibly have to continue on chemo throughout our life.. I have felt really great without toxins running through my body.
Posts.Title: Back to Chemo ChicagoGirl Shutterbug73

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2016 09:54AM ChicagoGirl wrote: Just got an email from the doctor and my scans came back stable. My oncologist has agreed to a break from the TDM1 and I will only have herceptin every 3wks.. This has been a very long 3 1/2 years, at diagnosis I was given a survival rate of 2 to 4 yrs and here I am today stable for a little over 2yrs now and going on 3 1/2 years of surviving this thing. I know and believe that anythings possible. I also had my last expansion yesterday and will have the exchange surgery April 8th. My plastic surgeon is very pleased with my healing and how everything has turned out. In the beginning I was truly nervous about the reconstructive surgery but now I'm really glad I did it and even more ecstatic I can feel like myself in a tank top ~sometimes its just the little things..
Posts.Title: Back to Chemo ChicagoGirl Shutterbug73

Posts.Content: ChicagoGirl wrote: Back to chemo I go Jan. 25th. I have been off since November 2015 as I had reconstructive surgery Dec. 4th. The surgery went well and my body feels great to have been without chemo toxins this long. Going back to chemo Jan. 25th really has me thinking, I am currently on TDM1 (Kadcyla) and have been on this med for about 2yrs, possibly longer and this seems to be the med that has worked best for me. Though I'm feeling great and not worrying too much, I do wonder if maybe continuing on the chemo is necessary ~maybe getting my oncologist opinion on switching to just herceptin and see how that goes but I realize it may be like playing with fire. I just wish I could be free of the if's, would, shoulds and coulds... Dx 10/21/2012, 6cm+, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Targeted Therapy 11/4/2012 Tykerb (lapatinib) Chemotherapy 1/31/2013 Taxotere (docetaxel) Targeted Therapy 11/4/2013 Herceptin (trastuzumab) Surgery 11/19/2013 Lymph node removal: Right; Mastectomy: Right Surgery Reconstruction (right): Latissimus dorsi flap Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Back to Chemo ChicagoGirl Shutterbug73

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2016 10:44AM ChicagoGirl wrote: Hi Ladies I spoke with my oncologist yesterday regarding my treatment plan and things went pretty well. I mentioned since I had been off chemo since November due to the reconstructive surgery I had been feeling great and asked can my treatment plan be reviewed. My current chemo is the TDM1 (kadcyla) every 3wks. I have been on this regiment for about 2 1/2yrs and have been stable over this time. I have now asked if I could just get the Herceptin without the TDM1, she didn't agree however she didn't disagree. The plan is for me to have scans which will be done Feb 3rd and based on the results of the scans we will go from there. I'm excited to have come this far along, being diagnosed at the age of 32 in 2012 and being told a survival rate of 2 to 4 years which I refuse to accept and also from being told a mastectomy and reconstructive surgery wouldn't be an option to where I am now... I'm just hoping all goes well with the scans. I'm worrried but not too worried..
Posts.Title: Back to Chemo ChicagoGirl Shutterbug73

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2016 05:53AM ChicagoGirl wrote: Scans came back stable and I'm happy to say I am on a chemo break!! For now only Herceptin every 3wks and the Xgeva every 6wks.. Hopefully my blood levels will go back to normal, whatever's considered normal for me! Shanette (()) to you all!
Posts.Title: Back to Chemo ChicagoGirl Shutterbug73

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2015 08:40PM - edited Aug 12, 2015 09:29PM by ChicagoGirl I remember meeting a new guy and telling him about being diagnosed with BC...His only reply was "so are you going to die"?? My reply to him was "well you know we're all going to die its called the cycle of life, you live and you die"!! He looked at me with such confusion..

I have scans May30th which will help me to decide.. Has anyone considered or done this?? Posts.Title: XGEVA let's talk about the good and the side effects dixiebell JFL

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2014 01:05PM ChicagoGirl wrote: Hello Trish, I have been on TDM1 since the summer of 13'. I was diagnosed Oct 2012 with mets to the liver and spine. I'm given bendryl and tylenol before the treatment which make me tired. Besides that I find it to be manageable. The few sides effects I have are a little neuropathy in my fingertips, a runny nose -oddly I read somewhere that was also a side effect, and dry mouth after the first few days after the treatment. Since being on TDM all scans have came back stable.. My doc has stated I will continue the TDM1 as long as it continues to work for me. I wish you well with the TDM1.
Posts.Title: Who's on Kadcyla/TDM1? Trish03 Denny123

Posts.Content: ChicagoGirl wrote: Hi Ladies, Just wanted to share an interview I recently did with a local Chicago news station on some mentoring I have been doing. In some odd way or maybe its not odd but being there for someone else gets me through. Allowing others to see this thing has not broken me. I pray I always have this hope and inspiration to give others.. http://www.nbcchicago.com/blogs/making-a-difference/WEB-430P-PKG-MENTOR-ANGEL_Chicago-373912751.html Shanette (ChicagoGirl) Dx 10/21/2012, 6cm+, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Targeted Therapy 11/4/2012 Tykerb (lapatinib) Chemotherapy 1/31/2013 Taxotere (docetaxel) Targeted Therapy 11/4/2013 Herceptin (trastuzumab) Surgery 11/19/2013 Lymph node removal: Right; Mastectomy: Right Surgery Reconstruction (right): Latissimus dorsi flap Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Keeping Positive ChicagoGirl artistatheart

Posts.Content: ChicagoGirl wrote: After almost 3yrs of treatment, a mastectomy and radiation to the chest wall my oncologist as well as the surgeon has given the okay for me to have reconstructive surgery of the right breast. I was really excited to hear this and feel I have come a long ways considering I had been told it wouldn't be any chance for reconstructive. However after almost a year of stable scans (nothing seen in the chest wall, the lesions of the liver are looking like scar tissue and remain stable and the same for the spine) they are okay with it. Funny because now that I have received the okay I've been wondering is it worth it. After meeting with the plastic surgeon and being told they would use the muscle from my back plus as well as an implant it sounds like a lot. Though it would make my feel like me again as its kind of hard being 36 and going thru so much. I would like to know if anyone has had the reconstructive surgery and how were things with it... My mastectomy and radiation was done almost 2yrs ago. Posts.Title: Taking a break ChicagoGirl Rosevalley

Posts.Content: May 13, 2014 05:35PM ChicagoGirl wrote: Rose, thank you for sharing, myonc pretty much said the same as you. She advised it wouldn't be a good thing to take a break from the chemo since I am tolerating the meds well and have minimum side effects. She explained sometimes taking a break from chemo can do much harm and when trying to go back to the meds the tumor may become resistant to treatment. I guess it was just wishful thinking.Continuing to pray and live life!!
Posts.Title: Taking a break ChicagoGirl Rosevalley

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2014 04:36PM ChicagoGirl wrote: Hi Amy, as per the last bone scan everything looks good and the mets on the spine looks more like scar tissue now from healing. But its just the side effect were all of a sudden after almost 2yrs. I will take your advice on the hot bath and also will take a couple of ibprofen. Hopefully i'll be better by the end of the week. thank you!
Posts.Title: Xgeva Side Effects ChicagoGirl ReadingMama

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2014 10:42PM ChicagoGirl wrote: I spoke with my oncologist and she said she wanted to have it done it three weeks and didn't want to have me off chemo for 6weeks. She's going to discuss this further with the radiology doctor and let me know. The nurse did mention a round of boosters. I'm just afraid it will take away from my daily life. I am a single parent with 2 boys ages 15 and 7. My plan would be to work from 6 to 3 then head to the doctor for radiation and come home and be super mommy..I feel like this is going to effect a lot. Really can't afford to miss work as I am raising two boys with no help.

Posts.Content: ChicagoGirl wrote: So I just got a call from the nurse in radiology and was advised I would have 30 rounds of radiation. I'm not a doctor but this sounds like a lot to me considering I was originally told 15 rounds. Is this too much radiation?? I am now waiting on a call to find out the the regimen changed. I'm thinking 15rounds as originally planned, scans thereafter and more radiation if needed. The thought of 30 rounds sounds like a lot...urgh!!! Beginiing to feel like this disease is controlling my life at times..I just wanna scream!!!
